body.name: Still Life: Chief Inspector Gamache, Book 1
body.description: Winner of the New Blood Dagger, Arthur Ellis, Barry, Anthony, and Dilys awards. Chief Inspector Armand Gamache of the Surêté du Québec and his team of investigators are called in to the scene of a suspicious death in a rural village south of Montreal. Jane Neal, a local fixture in the tiny hamlet of Three Pines, just north of the U.S. border, has been found dead in the woods. The locals are certain it’s a tragic hunting accident and nothing more, but Gamache smells something foul in these remote woods, and is soon certain that Jane Neal died at the hands of someone much more sinister than a careless bowhunter. Still Life introduces not only an engaging series hero in Inspector Gamache, who commands his forces - and this series - with integrity and quiet courage, but also a winning and talented new writer of traditional mysteries in the person of Louise Penny. Read more

productInformation.value: #2,032 in Audible Books & Originals (See Top 100 in Audible Books & Originals) #21 in Police Procedural Mysteries #150 in Police Procedurals (Books)

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 12, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars First one...get started
reviews.reviewText: instead of buying a set of five for a cheaper price, I thought I'd just try number one before investing in the series of 18. The story line is okay, but I liked it and thought,"Okay, I'll try number 2." HOOKED. My daughter is reading the series as is my cousin. Our only complaint is THERE ARE ONLY TWENTY FOUR HOURS IN A DAY and we can't read fast enough. We try to put a book aside, but Louise Penny's writing is addictive and heart reving. You gotta finish!!

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Intriguing first book in a series
reviews.reviewText: 4.5 stars…I’ve had this author and this series recommended to me several times and I finally decided it was time to give it a try. I’m glad I finally did. The book started out slowly and I was wondering if I’d made a mistake but when things finally picked up the story was totally engrossing and I my brain was completely engaged.Gamache is an interesting character and there is reference to an incident that stalled his career though we never get the details of it. Nonetheless he is a well respected homicide chief inspector. He has a unique way about him and his emphasis on observation immediately brings to mind Hercule Poirot. His right hand man is a god example of the archetype. The third member of the team however is a puzzle. She is annoying, irresponsible, and moronic in the extreme and I cannot believe that she continues beyond this book. There is nothing redeeming about her and it is puzzling that Gamache would keep her around after her actions in this case.Of course the other major character in the book is the village itself. Initially the whole thing is like reading a British country village mystery though the frequent French references and the clear cultural resentments do push in to bring you back to the setting. The villagers are an odd mix of people and certainly lend color to the proceedings.The climactic moment is exciting and the ending sets the stage for the next book. I will eagerly continue on with the series.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Look for what's missing, not what's there
reviews.reviewText: First in a series I was told was a must-read. I'm not quite convinced, but the main character, one Inspector Armand Gamache is intriguing as he seeks to find out what caused the death of one Jane Neal and who might have done it after he concludes it wasn't an accident.How the author weaves the clues in and out of the chapters, often revealed by yet another interesting, and flawed character makes for reading that kept me up far too late at night, the better to identify the murderer before any of the characters did. Alas, I didn't, but Inspector Armand did.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 16, 2024
reviews.reviewText: Storyline is OK, struggling a bit to get into it but my biggest complaint is the actual book size. It’s tiny! It’s like a pocket edition or something and is very uncomfortable to hold and keep open to read. I happened to order this book plus the 2nd book in this series, book 2 is a normal size. I’m surprised no one else has mentioned this.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 17, 2023
reviews.reviewText: One of the best written novels I have ever read. Not crazy about the homosexual content. It had nothing to do with the plot, but a lot of writers these days seem to add this in order to sell their books.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on January 19, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars What a great find!
reviews.reviewText: I recently discovered Louise Penny and her series with Inspector Gamache and the village of Three Pines. Love the writing, development of characters and the quaint setting of Three Pines. This first book was a great intro to her writing, and each one I've read since has not disappointed. I love getting to know the Inspector and others, plus picturing Three Pines. I'd love to visit there : )I highly recommend this series.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on February 1, 2024
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent Murder Mystery!
reviews.reviewText: I love the tiny town of Three Pines and all of the “characters” living there. The author does an excellent job of making you believe all of the residents of this Canadian village actually exist. Wondering who committed murder is almost secondary to learning about their residents’ lives.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on April 27, 2023
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Very Enjoyable With Reservations
reviews.reviewText: Once I got beyond the first few chapters and began to sort through the characters, this resolved into an enjoyable small town murder mystery in a slightly foreign setting (Canadian border town) mostly manifested in the odd French word or Quebecois cultural reference. I liked the perceptive and humane Inspector Gamache and his subordinate Beauvoir. My problems with the book manifested at the beginning with two pet peeves: too many characters introduced too quickly to keep track of (but whose relationships were of course important to the solution of the mystery) and the shifting point of view. In third person narration, I don’t mind getting inside the head of a few main characters, but the shifts happened abruptly, sometimes from one sentence to the next, occasionally leading to some confusion as to who was thinking these particular thoughts!This all made for a tangled web where I kept thinking I needed a browser to figure out when a given character had first appeared and what had been mentioned about them at the time.Probably the only character that aroused my emotions (very negatively!) was Nicole, to the point where I was more interested in seeing this rude, clueless and self-important young inspector get her comeuppance than I was in solving the murder.And also, did so many intelligent characters have be so behind the curve at the end? You just don’t confront the murderer with “I knew it was you” in a dark house in a hurricane!Nevertheless, I enjoyed the book enough that I will probably read the series. The writer’s skills became evident after the initial sorting out, and it’s rare enough to find a book written with both moral grace and intelligence that I’m glad to end the search for awhile.
Loved it. Deep without being pretentious. A mystery that never totally explained itself on many levels. Súper to read and hard to put down.

reviews.reviewTitle: Liked it but didn't love it
reviews.reviewText: Three Pines is somewhere everybody would like to visit/live (they'd hate me)Loved the detective and the storyBUT for meAgent Yvette Nichol was genius, every time she appeared I relished her performanceGod it's great not to have children

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United Kingdom on October 20, 2023
reviews.reviewText: I’ve read all 18 books in the series, and I wanted to finish them all before writing a review ofStill Life, the first book.I was captivated by the characters, the settings, and most of all the outstanding writing, from the start – but I think the author might forgive me when I say that my impression of the first book is that she was feeling her way forward with her characters and their predicaments. In subsequent books she knows her characters better and the fluency of her writing, already formidable in the first book, grows into something amazing.One thing that strikes me straight away, as someone who dabbled in being an author and who drew on the expertise of editors, is that Ms Penney has no fear of delving into the minds of all her fictional personalities. I was taught not to do ‘head-hopping’ by going from one character to another and revealing their thoughts, but after reading Ms Penney’s books I think that advice is flawed. In her novels, head-hopping works perfectly and adds to the pace and tension – and there is plenty of both. She conveys tension in such a way that I couldn’t put the books down, and although that is rather a cliché, in my case it is true. So much so, that I couldn’t pick up any other books by other authors until I’d finished the entire series and I was sad that there wasn’t a book 19 to be read.The pace is handled well – calm where it needs to be calm, and breathless where it needs to take off. For me, the various murders and deaths are only a part of the stories; pivotal points about which the lives and concerns of the cast swirl like several drama series in their own right. There is a wonderfully sharp observation of human nature and moments of humour which made me laugh rather than just chuckle.I know the books have been turned into a television drama series called Three Pines, and although I like Alfred Molina as the central character, Armand Gamache, I feel the TV series can’t do justice to the books. Like most TV adaptations, it doesn’t capture the flow of narrative, most of which is lost in the transition between book and film mediums.The books are superb. As the first one, Still Life is the gateway to a captivating experience, and I envy readers who haven’t yet delved into the delights of the other seventeen books. In fact, I think I might read the whole series a second time, just to enjoy the brilliant writing and story-telling.

Surprised that I haven't read any of Louise Penny's books so far.My complaint is directed towards whoever has created the digital version of Still Life. The first page of every chapter (every single one of them!) is missing! While it does not take away the overall pleasure of reading a book with a good plot, strong characters and a narrative which is paced well, one keeps wondering what one has missed on those pages.
